intro: Ranunculus consimilis, commonly known as the similar buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, often yellow or orange flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with trifoliate leaves and solitary flowers that bloom in early spring. Its flowers have five to eight sepals that resemble petals, and it produces small, green, oval fruits. Ranunculus consimilis is often found in moist meadows, woodland edges, and along stream banks.
